Luke.Action: Cheerfully hums and mumbles a tune while vandalizing parking meters, speaks playfully to the meters.
Grins and drinks beer smilingly when confronted by officers.
Skillfully uses a pipe cutter to disable parking meters, showing technical ability and confidence.
Cheerfully hums and talks to the meters while committing vandalism, indicating a relaxed and confident demeanor.
Drinks beer openly in front of approaching police officers, showing boldness but potentially poor judgment.
Stands with languid grace, neither insolent nor hostile, nor fearful among new prisoners.
Answers respectfully and honestly to the Captain's questions about his crime and military record.
Admits he wasn't thinking when cutting heads off parking meters.
Responds promptly and clearly when called by the Captain, showing attentiveness and confidence.
Admits to cutting heads off parking meters and acknowledges he wasn't thinking, indicating a lack of foresight or poor judgment.
Acknowledges his military record with humility and acceptance, showing self-awareness and composure.
Turns and walks away after the speech, showing calmness and control.
Winks at the doleful bloodhound, indicating awareness and subtle communication.
Mouths the rules along with Carr, showing attentiveness and understanding of the regulations.
Grins while other new men are bewildered, showing ease and friendliness in a tense situation.
Sits at the first vacant spot and begins to eat industriously while others hesitate, showing no hostility or selfishness but a calm, inclusive demeanor.
Grins confidently while others are bewildered; sits promptly at the first vacant spot and begins to eat industriously without confusion.
Snorts at Dragline's warning about rules, showing a lighthearted defiance.
Responds to Dragline's teasing with a smile and a witty remark about not hearing anything worth listening to yet.

Remains at the poker table while others are being assessed, showing calm and focus.
Shrugs off invitation to join poker game and walks away, showing disinterest or confidence in not needing to participate.
Lies in bunk staring at the bulb, seemingly contemplative and calm despite surroundings.

Responds to Dragline's exaggerated story with amusement and a casual explanation, demonstrating social ease and confidence.

Drops to the ground to examine a blister on his hand, showing awareness of his physical limits.

Stumbles past Dragline's advice without paying attention.
Stops working momentarily to look at a crow cawing overhead, showing distraction.

Flailing away like an automaton while working.
Comments wryly that the boss just said something after firing the rifle at the crow.
Heaves himself up to the third tier bunk despite exhaustion, responds agreeably and with a sense of humor about his punishment, indicating resilience and mental composure.
Is put in the box on his first day, apparently unaware of the chain gang's rules and customs, suggesting a lack of initial understanding or preparation.
Sarcastically comments that the guards need all the help they can get, then rolls over and goes to sleep instead of escalating conflict.
Rolls over and goes to sleep after a tense exchange, showing calmness and confidence in the face of potential conflict.
Has mastered the work rhythm and is tanned and hardened, indicating skill and adaptation to difficult labor.

Jokes with Tramp and Dragline, making lighthearted comments.

Engages in playful banter confidently, demonstrating social ease and wit.
Makes a crude, joking comment about the woman hosing the car, implying her husband is violent toward milkmen.
Tells Dragline to stop beating on the subject, saying 'You ain't doin' nobody no good.'
Grins after being hit with a glove and getting up, showing resilience and good-natured spirit.
Tells Dragline to stop beating and that he isn't doing anyone any good, attempting to de-escalate the situation.
After being hit with a glove and falling, he gets up, hurt and startled, but grins, showing resilience and readiness to continue.
Shakes his head and grins, saying 'I don't want to frighten him' before continuing to fight Dragline.

Shakes his head and grins, saying he doesn't want to frighten Dragline despite being warned to stay down.

Gets knocked down multiple times, dizzy and bleeding, but keeps getting up.
Despite repeated knockdowns and being clearly outmatched, continues to fight without adapting strategy or showing signs of tactical improvement.
Keeps getting up and grinning despite being beaten, shows resilience and good-natured defiance.
Engages in poker game with others, participating in social activity despite injury.

Struggles to raise his glove to punch, indicating physical limitation or exhaustion.

Plays poker quietly and expressionlessly, follows the flow without engaging socially.
Consistently calls 'Kick a buck' automatically during the poker game without showing emotion or hesitation.

Smiles and comments 'Nuthin' can be a pretty cool hand,' demonstrating wit and confidence in a difficult situation.
Encourages Dragline to work harder and keep pace, motivating others to increase effort.

Smiles and says 'Nothin'' in response to guards' concern, leading others to relax and laugh happily.
Sits up amazed when told a visitor is here, showing openness and receptiveness.

Sits up, staring unmoving and amazed when told a visitor has come, showing surprise and momentary distraction.
Greets his mother and family warmly during their visit, showing care and attention despite difficult circumstances.
Engages in casual, friendly conversation with Boss Paul and others at the gate, indicating openness and approachability.
Does not display any hostility or coldness toward visitors or family, even though the environment is tense and controlled.

Engages in brief, somewhat guarded conversation with his mother and others, indicating controlled social skills and situational awareness.
Does not display any overtly skillful or confident behavior in this excerpt beyond basic social interaction and composure.

Acknowledges Arletta's efforts but states his problems are his own, showing some emotional distance.

Admits uncertainty about his future and personal problems, indicating some vulnerability and lack of clear direction.
Expresses understanding and sympathy toward his mother’s pain and disappointment, tries to change the subject gently.

Admits to trying to live free and aboveboard but notes the lack of freedom, showing some sincerity.
Mentions the girl his mother liked but notes she left him, without bitterness or blame.
Responds calmly and confidently to his mother's disappointment, tries to reassure her by saying 'Nothin'. Ever'thing's cool's can be.'
Acknowledges the lack of freedom and opportunity realistically: 'Tried to live always just as free and aboveboard as you been, and well, they ain't that much elbow room.'

Shows awareness of Arletta's feelings and the situation, but does not act to change it.

Explains to John-Boy the reality of punishment and mistakes with calm clarity and confidence.
Sits on his bunk plunking aimlessly at the banjo, showing a lack of purposeful action or focus.

Mocks or taunts the approaching storm as 'the Big Boss' getting ready to 'let us have it!'
